description: Tucson Electric Power's Smart Demand Response (SmartDR) Program offers large commercial, industrial, and institutional customers the opportunity to reduce energy costs by reducing energy use at times of high demand or system constraints. Customers develop customized Energy Reduction Plans with TEP and receive quarterly bill credits based on their performance during load reduction events. The program provides flexibility with no penalties for opting out of individual events, though credits will be lower. No special equipment is required.

service_territories: TEP service area (Pima County and surrounding areas in Southern Arizona)
geography.notes: TEP is a subsidiary of UNS Energy Corporation, which is owned by Fortis Inc.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Designed for larger commercial, industrial, and institutional customers

eligibility.notes: Program allows both direct participation and aggregated participation. Customers can participate individually or through an aggregator. Piclo Energy has listed this program on their platform as a marketplace opportunity.

notification.notification_notes: TEP contacts program participants when the demand for energy is high and asks them to reduce usage according to their Energy Reduction Plan. Specific advance notice period not publicly disclosed. For comparison, TEP's Interruptible Service program provides 30-minute notice.

capacity_rate.notes: Program provides quarterly bill credits based on agreed curtailment and performance during events. Specific $/kW rates are not publicly disclosed. TEP's Interruptible Service program (a related but different program) offers $2.25/kW MVCP (Market Value Capacity Price) for comparison. SmartDR rates likely differ and may be customized per participant.

performance_rate.notes: Program primarily offers quarterly bill credits rather than per-event performance payments. Credits are based on agreed curtailment capacity and actual performance during events.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalty or fee for opting out of demand response dispatches, but quarterly credit will be lower if customer does not respond to events.

payment_structure.payment_notes: Quarterly bill credits applied based on performance. No upfront costs. Customers can opt out of individual events without penalties, though this reduces their quarterly credit amount. Program is designed to be flexible and customer-friendly.

seasons.notes: TEP defines summer as May through September. Events are most likely during this period due to high cooling demand in Arizona. TEP experienced peak demand records during summer heat waves.
Events less common but possible during winter months. Program operates year-round but with primary focus on summer peaks.

call_windows.notes: Arizona does not observe Daylight Saving Time. Specific event call windows not publicly disclosed. Events typically occur during periods of high demand, which in Arizona are typically afternoon/early evening hours during summer heat.

event_parameters.notes: Documentation indicates events typically last 'several hours'. Specific parameters not publicly disclosed. Events are called during high demand periods and system constraints.

event_triggers.trigger_description: Events are called when demand for power is high or when there are system constraints. In Arizona, this is primarily during extreme heat conditions in summer months when cooling loads drive peak demand. TEP experienced record-breaking peak demand during summer 2024 heat waves, highlighting the importance of demand response resources.
event_triggers.examples: In summer 2024, Arizona utilities (APS, TEP, SRP) broke peak demand records during extreme heat. TEP has called events during these conditions to maintain grid reliability.

nomination_bidding.notes: Customers must enroll by contacting TEP's Commercial Energy Solutions department and developing an Energy Reduction Plan. Enrollment appears to be ongoing rather than limited to specific seasonal periods. Piclo Energy marketplace listed the program as 'inactive or no longer accepting new applicants' as of September 2025, but TEP's website still shows the program as active - status should be verified with TEP directly.

special_attributes: Flexible Energy Reduction Plans customized to business needs
No penalties for opting out of events
Plans can be adjusted at any time
Helps ensure grid reliability and energy affordability
Can participate directly or through aggregator

program_evolution.change_description: Program established to provide demand response resources for TEP's system

program_history.notes: Program history not well documented in public sources. TEP also offers related programs including Interruptible Service (minimum 3,000 kW demand, 1,000 kW curtailment) and residential programs like Smart Rewards and Energy Storage Rewards.

historical_events.notes: Arizona utilities (APS, TEP, SRP) broke peak demand records during extreme heat in summer 2024. Specific SmartDR event details not publicly available.

interruptible_service.description: TEP's firm interruptible program for large commercial customers with higher capacity requirements
interruptible_service.payment_type: bill credits for months with interruptions
interruptible_service.equipment_requirements: Customer responsible for communication, relay, and breaker equipment
interruptible_service.interruption_rights: Can be interrupted at any time for any reason; customer waives claims for losses
interruptible_service.notes: More stringent requirements than SmartDR but higher and more predictable payment rate. Good comparison point for SmartDR economics.

smart_rewards.description: Residential smart thermostat demand response program
smart_rewards.notes: In summer 2024, Smart Rewards participants collectively saved enough energy across nine events to power equivalent of 2,300 homes

energy_storage_rewards.description: Residential battery storage demand response program

verification_sources.source_name: TEP Smart Demand Response Program Page
Piclo Energy - TEP SmartDR Program Listing
DOE FEMP Western States DR Programs Database
Utility Dive - Arizona Utilities Peak Demand Records

missing_critical_data: Event duration parameters (typical, min, max hours)
Temperature or price thresholds for event triggers
data_not_publicly_available: Payment rates - likely customized per participant based on capacity and performance commitments
Detailed Energy Reduction Plan templates or requirements
Program evaluation reports or impact assessments
Arizona Corporation Commission tariff filings for SmartDR
verification_limitations: TEP's website provides only high-level program description
No publicly available tariff sheets specifically for SmartDR program
Payment rates not disclosed - requires direct contact with TEP
Most operational details require enrollment to access
Piclo Energy shows program as 'inactive' but TEP website shows active - conflicting information on current status
No access to TEP's 2023 IRP PDF (file too large) which may contain detailed program information
Arizona Corporation Commission docket system not searched for regulatory filings
No case studies or participant testimonials publicly available

research_notes: Conducted web research on TEP SmartDR program on 2025-10-11. Program is minimally documented in public sources with only basic information available on TEP's website. Key program parameters (payment rates, capacity requirements, event frequency/duration, notification periods) are not publicly disclosed. TEP's Interruptible Service program provides useful comparison point - it offers $2.25/kW MVCP with 30-minute notice, but has much higher thresholds (3,000 kW demand, 1,000 kW curtailment) and more stringent requirements (can be interrupted anytime, customer liable for equipment, waives damage claims). SmartDR appears designed as more flexible, lower-threshold alternative with no penalties and adjustable plans. Piclo Energy marketplace listed program but shows as 'inactive or no longer accepting new applicants' as of Sept 2025, while TEP's website still promotes the program - this conflict needs resolution. TEP experienced peak demand records in summer 2024, demonstrating ongoing need for DR resources. For complete program details, direct contact with TEP Commercial Energy Solutions (520-745-3425 or smartdr@tep.com) required. Overall data quality is poor due to lack of public documentation - suitable for general awareness but insufficient for detailed economic modeling or optimization without additional information gathering.

integration_metadata.api_notes: No evidence of API availability. Program appears to operate via manual notification (phone/email) and response.
integration_metadata.verification_thoroughness: Basic web research conducted including program webpage, related program pages, marketplace listings, news articles, and regulatory context. Limited by lack of public documentation. Did not access: ACC regulatory filings, TEP tariff sheets, IRP detailed analysis (file too large), direct contact with TEP.
recommended_next_steps: Contact TEP Commercial Energy Solutions (520-745-3425, smartdr@tep.com) to request detailed program information including payment rates, capacity requirements, and enrollment materials
Search Arizona Corporation Commission docket system for TEP SmartDR tariff filings and regulatory approvals
Download and review TEP 2023 IRP (may need to request from TEP if PDF too large for web access)
Request sample Energy Reduction Plan template to understand commitment requirements
Clarify current program status - resolve conflict between Piclo (inactive) and TEP website (active)
Request historical event log to understand actual call frequency and timing patterns
Interview current or past participants if possible
Compare economics vs TEP Interruptible Service to understand when SmartDR is advantageous
Determine if program is compatible with battery energy storage systems or primarily load curtailment
Request M&V procedures and baseline calculation methodology
integration_metadata.notes: Program appears active and operational but is poorly documented publicly. The low data quality score (4/10) reflects significant gaps in critical information needed for economic analysis or system optimization. Main value proposition is flexibility and ease of participation compared to more stringent Interruptible Service program. No penalties for non-performance is attractive but suggests lower payment rates. Quarterly payment structure provides steady revenue but less responsive to individual event participation compared to per-event payments. Limited utility for battery optimization modeling without additional data gathering. TEP's service territory is not part of an ISO/RTO, operating as traditional vertically integrated utility, which may limit transparency vs ISO markets. Arizona's extreme summer heat (peak demand records in 2024) creates strong value proposition for DR resources.
